Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION General
Subsubsection Text: Other than as described below under “—Issuer”, the historical financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum is the consolidated financial information of TeamSystem Holdco, the reporting entity of the TeamSystem Group. In particular, we have included and discussed the historical consolidated financial information comprising: (1) the audited consolidated financial statements of TeamSystem Holdco as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, including comparative information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 and the auditor’s report thereto, prepared in accordance with IFRS (the “2023 Financial Statements”); (2) the audited consolidated financial statements of TeamSystem Holdco as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, including comparative information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 (see “—Comparability of the Financial Statements”) and the auditor’s report thereto, prepared in accordance with IFRS (the “2022 Financial Statements” and, together with the 2023 Financial Statements, the “Audited Financial Statements”); and (3) the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements of TeamSystem Holdco as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2024, including unaudited comparative information for the three months ended March 31, 2023, prepared in accordance with International Accounting Standard 34 “Interim Financial Reporting” (the “Unaudited Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited Financial Statements, the “Consolidated Financial Statements”). Our Audited Financial Statements have been audited by Deloitte & Touche S.p.A. The Audited Consolidated Financial Statements are presented in euro and have been prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union and should be read in conjunction with the relevant notes thereto. As further described below under “—Comparability of the Financial Statements,” the comparative financial information of TeamSystem Holdco for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the 2022 Financial Statements and presented in this Offering Memorandum comprises the results of the 2021 TeamSystem Group (as defined below) only since its acquisition by Brunello Bidco on February 18, 2021. Such information is therefore not fully comparable with the financial information of TeamSystem Holdco presented in this Offering Memorandum for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023. In addition, as the historical financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum and the Consolidated Financial Statements relate to TeamSystem Holdco, they diverge from certain consolidated historical financial information of the Issuer also included in this Offering Memorandum with respect to the Issuer, primarily due to the Existing PIK Notes issued by Holdco 3, a subsidiary of TeamSystem Holdco and the direct shareholder of the Issuer. For more information on these differences, see “—The Issuer.” Certain line items in the revenue breakdown by business unit presented in this Offering Memorandum have been reclassified, as further described in “—Business units and revenue breakdowns.” In addition, in our 2022 Financial Statements and 2023 Financial Statements, the comparative financial information as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2022, respectively, was restated to reflect the completion of the purchase price allocation to goodwill in relation to certain acquisitions that occurred in 2021 and 2022, respectively. As a result, our consolidated statement of financial position for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022 presented in this Offering Memorandum have been derived from the corresponding comparative column in the 2022 Financial Statements and in the 2023 Financial Statements respectively (and not from the Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 and the 2022). For more information, see “—Impact of bolt-on _acquisitions made by the TeamSystem Group.”_ The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. It also requires the board of directors to exercise its judgment in the process of applying accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where assumptions and estimates are significant to our financial statements, are disclosed in our Consolidated Financial Statements. See also “Management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations—Critical accounting _policies.”_ -----

Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION General
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is indirectly controlled by TeamSystem Holdco and is the surviving entity of a merger pursuant to Article 2501-bis of the Italian Civil Code between Brunello Bidco S.p.A. (i.e. the entity which originally issued the Existing Senior Secured Notes), Barolo Luxco 1 S.p.A., TeamSystem Holding S.p.A. and the Issuer (the “Merger”), which was completed on October 26, 2021 (“Merger Date”). As a result of the Merger, and starting from the Merger Date, the Issuer assumed, inter alia, all the obligations of Brunello Bidco S.p.A. with respect to the Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility. While the historical financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum and the Consolidated Financial Statements appended hereto are of TeamSystem Holdco, we also present in this Offering Memorandum certain consolidated historical financial information of the Issuer and its subsidiaries. Such information has been calculated by netting the relevant amount pertaining to TeamSystem Holdco and the intermediate holding companies sitting between TeamSystem Holdco and the Issuer in the corporate structure of the TeamSystem Group from the consolidated financial information of TeamSystem Holdco. In addition, we present in this Offering Memorandum certain financial information of the Issuer (which has been calculated pursuant to the above) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 on an adjusted basis, to give pro forma_ effect to the Transactions, as if the Transactions had occurred on March 31, 2024 for the as adjusted statement of financial position information and on April 1, 2023 for the as adjusted statement of profit or loss information. See “—As adjusted financial information for the Transactions.” The financial information in respect of the Issuer described above has not been audited or reviewed in accordance with International Standards on Auditing or any other generally accepted auditing standards.

Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION General
Subsubsection Text: On February 18, 2021, Brunello Bidco S.p.A., the predecessor of the Issuer before the Merger and an indirect subsidiary of Holdco (“Brunello Bidco”), indirectly acquired (the “2021 Acquisition”) all the issued share capital of the Issuer (and together with the Issuer’s then existing subsidiaries, the “2021 TeamSystem Group”). As a result, TeamSystem Holdco’s consolidated statement of profit or loss and statement of cash flows information for the year ended December 31, 2021 comprise the results of the 2021 TeamSystem Group only since its acquisition by Brunello Bidco on February 18, 2021. The financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 was not restated to reflect the results of operations of the 2021 TeamSystem Group for the full 2021 year, including the period from January 1, 2021 to the date of completion of the 2021 Acquisition. As a result of the impact of the 2021 Acquisition on TeamSystem HoldCo’s financial information for the year ended December 31, 2021, the statement of profit or loss and statement of cash flows for such year included in the comparative column in the 2022 Financial Statements and presented in this Offering Memorandum are not fully comparable with the statement of profit or loss or the statement of cash flows for any subsequent year. The consolidated financial information for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the comparative column in the 2022 Financial Statements presented elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum does not give pro forma effect to the 2021 Acquisition as if it had been completed on January 1, 2021, nor was it restated to give effect to such impact. As a result, such information includes only the consolidated results of operations of the 2021 TeamSystem Group from the date of completion of the 2021 Acquisition (February 18, 2021) to December 31, 2021. See “Management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations—Factors affecting the _comparability of our results of operations—The 2021 Acquisition.”_ However, in order to facilitate the comparison between the periods under review, this Offering Memorandum presents certain unaudited consolidated financial information of the 2021 TeamSystem Group for the year ended December 31, 2021 that give pro forma effect to the 2021 Acquisition as if it had been completed on January 1, 2021 (the “2021 Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information”). The 2021 Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information have been calculated on the basis of management estimates and assumptions and has not been subject to any audit or review procedures carried out by any independent auditor. While we believe that the 2021 Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information can be useful to potential investors seeking to evaluate our performance over time, such financial data is not compliant with IFRS or any other accounting standards. Such 2021 Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information have been prepared by, and is the responsibility of, management. The 2021 Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information are based on a number of assumptions and estimates (including the elimination of certain non-recurring costs relating to the 2021 Acquisition, the inclusion of the costs and interest relating to the _pro forma capital structure of the 2021 ----- TeamSystem Group as it were in place since January 1, 2021, the inclusion of the results of the businesses that the 2021 TeamSystem Group acquired through 2021 as if such acquisitions had been consummated on January 1, 2021 as well as other assumptions and estimates) that are subject to inherent uncertainties and you are strongly cautioned against placing undue reliance thereon. The preparation of this financial data requires management to exercise judgment and make assumptions and for these reasons, the 2021 Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information are only a simulation of the 2021 TeamSystem Group’s results had the 2021 Acquisition been completed on January 1, 2021 and they are not an indication of what our results would have been had the 2021 Acquisition been completed on such date. The 2021 Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is subject to significant risks and uncertainties. See “Risk factors—Risks related to our Financial Information—Certain _audited financial information for the year ended December 31, 2021 presented in this Offering Memorandum are not fully comparable with the statement of profit or loss or the statement of cash flows for any subsequent year; the 2021 Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is for information purposes only, is only intended to simulate what our results of operations would have been had the 2021 Acquisition completed on January 1, 2021 and has been prepared on the basis of certain estimates and assumptions which we consider reasonable, but it is not a substitute for our Audited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.”_

Subsection Title: Unaudited financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024
Subsubsection Text: The historical unaudited consolidated financial information of TeamSystem Holdco for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 presented in this Offering Memorandum is calculated by adding each relevant statement of profit or loss line item for the three months ended March 31, 2024 to the corresponding statement of profit or loss line item for the year ended December 31, 2023 and subtracting from such sum the corresponding statement of profit or loss line item for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This data has been prepared solely for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum, is not prepared in the ordinary course of TeamSystem Holdco’s financial reporting and has not been audited or reviewed by TeamSystem Holdco’s independent auditors.

Subsection Title: Impact of bolt-on acquisitions made by the TeamSystem Group
Subsubsection Text: Our operating results and their comparability for the historical periods covered by the Consolidated Financial Statements are impacted by the effects of various bolt-on acquisitions made by the TeamSystem Group in such periods. Between 2021 and March 31, 2024, we acquired majority stakes in or the entire capital stock of 62 companies (excluding the transactions where we only increased our stake in previously acquired companies). In particular, we made eight acquisitions in 2021, 13 acquisitions in 2022, 30 acquisitions in 2023 and 11 acquisitions during the three months ended March 31, 2024. Due to the changes in our scope of consolidation as a consequence of each of such acquisitions, our results of operations in the periods under review may not be entirely comparable. For further information, see “Management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations—Key factors affecting our results of operations—Acquisitions”_ and “Management’s discussion and _analysis of financial condition and results of operations—Factors affecting the comparability of our results of operations—Bolt-on acquisitions made by the Group.”_ In our 2022 Financial Statements and 2023 Financial Statements, the comparative financial information as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2022, respectively, was restated to reflect the completion of the purchase price allocation to goodwill in relation to certain acquisitions that occurred in 2021 and 2022, respectively. See “Management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of _operations—Key factors affecting our results of operations—Acquisitions.” Therefore, (i) the financial_ information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included and discussed in this Offering Memorandum is that presented in the comparative column in our 2022 Financial Statements; and (ii) the financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 included and discussed in this Offering Memorandum is that presented in the comparative column in our 2023 Financial Statements, which was not covered by the audit report included therein.

Subsection Title: Business units and revenue breakdowns
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we present breakdowns of our revenue by our six business units corresponding to accounting segments under IFRS 8 (Operating Segments) in our Consolidated Financial Statements: - _Enterprise Solutions, which includes revenues deriving from the sales of products and services for SMEs, primarily core offerings such as ERP systems, along with additional accessory products and industryspecific solutions. ----- - _Professional Solutions, which mainly includes revenues deriving from the sales of products and services for professionals and labor consultants, focusing on accounting, tax and payroll, including professional education services. - _Market Specific Solutions,_ which includes revenues deriving from the sales of vertical solutions aimed at highly specialized markets, such as, among others, mechanical and manufacturing, construction, CAF/public sectors and legal. - _Micro Solutions,_ which mainly includes revenues deriving from the sales of our cloud-based products designed to address the needs of small and micro enterprises, vertical solutions for highly specialized industries such as wellness and hospitality as well as revenues deriving from our international sales. - _Digital Finance Solutions,_ which includes revenues deriving from the sales of products and services related to financial digitalization. - _Cross-Segment Product Solutions,_ which includes revenues deriving from the sales of modular human resources (“HR”) system solutions that address all HR management and business process outsourcing needs as well as trust solutions products. This accounting segment was referred to as “HR” in the Audited Financial Statements and has been renamed to its current name in the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements following the inclusion of trust solutions from the Market Specific Solutions accounting segment. For more information on our new business unit structure, see “Business—Our Business Units.” Certain line items in the revenue breakdown by business unit presented in this Offering Memorandum have been reclassified following the reallocation of revenue derived from our Trust Solutions product offering from the Market Specific Solutions business unit to the HR business unit, which is reflected in our Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. As a result of this reallocation, a new business unit, now referred to as “Cross-Segment Products,” was created, replacing the former HR business unit. Therefore, the revenue breakdown by business unit for the periods and fiscal years prior to March 31, 2024, presented in this Offering Memorandum, has been made based on same classification that is reflected in our Unaudited Interim Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: As adjusted financial information for the Transactions
Subsubsection Text: We present in this Offering Memorandum certain financial information on an adjusted basis, to give _pro forma effect to the Transactions, as if the Transactions had occurred on March 31, 2024 for the as adjusted statement of financial position information and on April 1, 2023 for the as adjusted statement of profit or loss information. For a description of the pro forma effect of the Transactions, including the issuance of the Notes offered hereby and the application of the proceeds therefrom, see “Summary historical financial information and other data—Other _financial and pro forma data,” “Capitalization” and “Use of proceeds.” Such as adjusted financial information is_ based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable and may differ from actual amounts. It is for informational purposes only and does not purport to present what our results or other metric would actually have been had the Transactions occurred on the dates presented or to project our results of operations or financial position for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. This as adjusted information has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X under the U.S. Exchange Act, the Prospectus Regulation, the UK Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting principles, including U.S. GAAP. Neither the adjustments nor the resulting as adjusted financial information have been audited or reviewed in accordance with International Standards on Auditing or any other generally accepted auditing standards. The as adjusted information should be read in conjunction with our Consolidated Financial Statements, including the notes thereto, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, “Management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations” and “Risk Factors.”

Subsection Title: Non-IFRS financial measures
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain non-IFRS measures, including Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin, pro forma total revenue, _Pro forma adjusted financial debt, Pro forma cash, cash equivalents and other financial assets, Pro forma adjusted_ net financial debt, Pro forma adjusted senior secured net financial debt, Pro forma adjusted net interest expense, net working capital, capital expenditure, total financial debt, net financial debt, recurring revenues, organic revenue growth, cloud revenue, adjusted operating cash flow, cash flow conversion rate, ratio of capital expenditure (net of capitalized development costs) to total revenue, ratio of allowance for bad debts to total ----- revenue, ratio of personnel costs to total revenue, total revenue per employee, Adjusted EBITDA per employee, and annualized recurring revenues that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS (the “Non-IFRS

Subsection Title: Measures and Ratios”). We believe that the presentation of these Non-IFRS Measures and Ratios is helpful to
Subsubsection Text: We do not, as a matter of course, make public projections as to future sales, earnings or other results. In this Offering Memorandum, however, we have presented certain _Pro Forma_ Adjusted EBITDA measures for the purposes of illustrating, among other things, the impact of certain initiatives that we have recently taken in order to improve our profitability. We believe that Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA provides a useful indication of what our Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 would have been under certain circumstances and assumptions as described herein. See “Summary historical financial information and other data—Other _financial and pro forma data” and “Risk factors—Risks related to our business—We have presented certain adjusted and pro forma financial information in this Offering Memorandum that is based upon management estimates including in respect of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA for certain cost saving initiatives, annualized recurring revenues, Adjusted EBITDA generated from bolt-on acquisitions. The relevance of these measures depends upon the accuracy of a series of estimates and assumptions involving factors that are beyond our control and are subject to known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors.”_ The assumptions used in estimating these _Pro Forma_ Adjusted EBITDA components are forward-looking in nature, inherently uncertain and subject to a variety of business, economic and competitive risks and uncertainties. We cannot assure you that the information on which we have based our assumptions will not change or that we will be able to realize any of the as-yet unrealized cost savings or revenue benefits we believe are possible based on these management estimates and assumptions. Furthermore, the costs we incur in trying to realize these cost savings may be substantially higher than our current estimates and may outweigh any benefit. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA does not represent the results we would have achieved (x) had the relevant cost saving initiatives been implemented as of April 1, 2023 and (y) had all of the relevant subscription agreements relating to our key cloud products (existing as of March 31, 2024) been in place as of April 1, 2023 and had all subscription fees thereunder been regularly paid by our customers for the entire relevant period. In addition, _Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA includes a pro forma adjustment for the contribution to our Adjusted EBITDA of certain bolt-on acquisitions for the periods and as further specified under “Summary—Summary historical financial information and other data— _Other financial and pro forma data.” Such adjustment does not reflect the costs we will incur to, among other_ things, integrate such businesses into the Group or any potential revenue or cost synergies or other impacts related to or expected to derive from such acquisitions, and, therefore, is not meant to represent what the contribution of such businesses to our Adjusted EBITDA would have been for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 if we had acquired and consolidated such businesses on April 1, 2023. Certain of such acquisitions are presently only subject to executed acquisition agreements, the consummation of which is subject to certain closing conditions, and there can be no assurance or guarantee that the consummation of these acquisitions will occur. _Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA was not prepared with a view toward complying with the guidelines established by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants with respect to prospective financial information; however, in the view of our management, this information was prepared on a reasonable basis, reflects the best currently available estimates and judgments, and presents, to the best of our managements’ knowledge and belief, our expected course of action and expected future financial performance. Neither our independent auditors, nor any other independent accountants, have compiled, examined, or performed any procedures with respect to the _Pro Forma_ Adjusted EBITDA measures contained herein, nor have they expressed any opinion or any other form of assurance on such information or its achievability, and assume no responsibility for, and disclaim any association with, the prospective financial information.

Subsection Title: Measures and Ratios”). We believe that the presentation of these Non-IFRS Measures and Ratios is helpful to
Subsubsection Text: investors because these and other similar measures and ratios are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. However, investors should not place any undue reliance on these Non-IFRS Measures and Ratios as financial indicators and should not consider these measures as: (a) alternatives to operating income or net income as determined in accordance with IFRS, or as measures of operating performance; (b) alternatives to cash flows from operating, investing or financing activities (as determined in accordance with IFRS), or as measures of our ability to meet cash needs; or (c) alternatives to any other measures of performance under IFRS. These measures are not indicative of historical operating results, nor are they meant to be predictive of future results. These measures are used by management to monitor our underlying performance and our business and operations. Since companies do not calculate these measures in an identical manner, our presentation may not be consistent with similar measures used by other companies. In addition, the presentation of these Non-IFRS Measures and Ratios is not intended to, and does not comply with, the reporting requirements of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”) and will not be subject to review by the SEC; compliance with its requirements would require us to make changes to the presentation of this information. Therefore, investors should not place undue reliance on the Non-IFRS Measures and Ratios. An explanation of the relevance of each of the Non-IFRS Measures and Ratios, a reconciliation of the Non-IFRS Measures and Ratios to the most directly comparable measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS and a discussion of their limitations is set out in this Offering Memorandum under “Summary historical financial _information and other data—Other financial and pro forma data.” We do not regard these non-IFRS measures as_ a substitute for, or superior to, the equivalent measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS or those calculated using financial measures that are calculated in accordance with IFRS. In particular, our EBITDA-based measures have limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in isolation or as a substitute for the analysis of our results or any performance measures under IFRS as set forth in our Consolidated Financial Statements. Some of the limitations relating to EBITDA-based measures are: - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest or principal payments on our debt; - they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay; - they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our statement of profit or loss; - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations; - although amortization, depreciation and write-downs are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated or amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and certain of these non-IFRS measures do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements; and - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. Because of these limitations, EBITDA-based measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our results reported under IFRS and using these EBITDA-based measures only to supplement your evaluation of our performance. These indicators should not be considered in isolation or construed as a substitute for measures in accordance with IFRS. For a description of Pro forma adjusted financial debt, Pro forma cash, cash equivalents and other financial assets, _Pro forma adjusted net financial debt, Pro forma adjusted senior secured net financial debt, Pro forma adjusted_ ----- net interest expense, net working capital, capital expenditure, total financial debt, net financial debt, recurring revenues, organic revenue growth, cloud revenue, adjusted operating cash flow, cash flow conversion rate, ratio of capital expenditure (net of capitalized development costs) to total revenue, ratio of allowance for bad debts to total revenue, ratio of personnel costs to total revenue, total revenue per employee, Adjusted EBITDA per employee, and annualized recurring revenues, see “Summary historical financial information and other data— _Other financial and pro forma data.”_

Subsection Title: Customers and Customer Retention Rate
Subsubsection Text: The statements regarding the number of our customers contained in this Offering Memorandum are derived from company internal data from (i) our licensing system, which also tracks solutions activated by VARs’ end-customers, (ii) our invoicing systems, which are used by our administration teams to track end-customers data (name, address, VAT number, etc.) and all the information needed to invoice them, (iii) our In Cloud product line customers database, (iv) our TeamSystem Digital platform, containing all the information on the digital customers connected through our accountant customers to our platform for e-invoicing services and (v) our international product line customer database containing information on our Spanish and Turkish business operations. ----- In calculating the number of customers, each person or entity that purchases one or more products from one of our business lines (including purchases made by digital customers connected through their accountants) is considered as one customer. The statements and data regarding Customer Retention Rate contained in this Offering Memorandum are derived from internal company data from our invoicing system and from management estimates. Data relating to Customer Retention Rate, as presented in this Offering Memorandum, is calculated as: (a) for our enterprise and professional customers, 1 less churn rate, where churn rate for any given year is the ratio of (i) the total recurring revenues for the prior year associated with customers who churned during the current year, to (ii) the total recurring revenues for such prior year; and (b) for our micro and small businesses customers and our customers with a subscription contract, 1 less churn rate, where churn rate for any twelve-month period ending in a given month is the ratio of (i) the total recurring revenues for the same month of the prior year associated with customers who churned between such month of the prior year and the same month of the current year, to (ii) the total recurring revenues for such month of the prior year. For the sake of clarity, in each case, Customer Retention Rate is calculated on the prior year or twelve-month period perimeter, as applicable, and excludes the positive impact of price adjustments and of the additional recurring revenues from cross-sell or up-sell to existing customers and from sales to new customers generated during the current period. We believe that our estimates regarding the number of our customers and the calculation of our Customer Retention Rate are fair and adequate. However, they are not part of our Consolidated Financial Statements and have not been audited or otherwise have not been verified by an outside auditor, consultant or independent expert.

Subsection Title: Rounding
Subsubsection Text: The figures included in this Offering Memorandum are expressed in millions of euros (except where otherwise indicated) since this is the currency used in the conduct of the TeamSystem Group’s operations. Certain amounts reported in this Offering Memorandum, including financial information and certain operating data, have been subject to rounding adjustments due to the presentation of figures in millions of euros. Accordingly, in certain cases, the sum of the numbers in a column or a row in tables may not correspond exactly to the total figure given for that column or row.

The global consulting company research publications consist of the opinions of its research organization and should not be construed as statements of fact. The global consulting company disclaims all warranties, expressed or implied, with respect to this research, including any warranties of merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose. Certain market related information derived from the Global Consulting Company Report and reproduced in this Offering Memorandum, such as data in respect of the overall ERP and business management software market in Italy, includes large enterprises. As we do not operate in the large enterprise customer segment, the data relating to share in a given segment we present throughout this Offering Memorandum, which are based on the report prepared by IDC, reflect our competitive position in each of the SME and micro and small businesses and professional customer segments only, therefore excluding the large enterprise customer segment. Information regarding Italian GDP and on the number of SMEs in the EU is derived or based on data from the Italian National Institute for Statistics (ISTAT) and the European Commission (Eurostat), DESI 2023 Indicators (DESI 2023), Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), Ministerio de Industria y Turismo, GOV UK and the European Commission (Eurostat). In many cases, there is no readily available external information (whether from trade associations, government bodies or other organizations) to validate market-related analyses and estimates, requiring us to rely on our own internally developed estimates regarding the industries in which we operate, our position in the relevant industry, our share and the shares of various industry participants in a given segment based on our experience, our own investigation of market conditions and our review of industry publications, including information made available to the public by our competitors. Neither we nor any of the Initial Purchasers can assure you of the accuracy and completeness of, or take any responsibility for, such data. Similarly, while we believe our internal estimates to be ----- reasonable, these estimates have not been verified by any independent sources and neither we nor the Initial Purchasers can assure you as to their accuracy or the accuracy of the underlying assumptions used to estimate such data. Our estimates involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors. See “Risk factors,” “Industry” and “Business” for further discussion regarding our industry and market data and the risks related thereto. -----

In this Offering Memorandum, information regarding markets, market size, shares and positioning in certain segments, growth rates and other industry data pertaining to our business was estimated or derived based on reports prepared by third party industry consultants, including, among others, NielsenIQ (“Nielsen”), IDC Corporate USA (“IDC”) and a global consulting company. In particular, (i) data relating to share in a given segment are based on an industry report prepared by IDC, (ii) net promoter score (“NPS”) data are based on an industry report prepared by Nielsen and (iii) certain data relating to the Italian ERP and business management market are based on a global consulting company report. The report prepared by IDC was prepared at our request in 2023, is based upon market data for 2023 and is the most recently available market data as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. The report prepared by Nielsen was prepared at our request in 2023 and is based upon data as of the last quarter of 2023. While Nielsen has accepted to have its name mentioned as source in this Offering Memorandum, no warranty or representation is made by Nielsen regarding the data sourced from Nielsen, and Nielsen does not accept any liability whatsoever to investors in respect of any data presented in this Offering Memorandum and investors should not rely on Nielsen data. Industry publications and forecasts generally state that the information they contain has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. While we believe that each of these studies and publications is reliable, neither we nor the Initial Purchasers have independently verified such data and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. When we refer to the micro and small businesses customer segment, mid-market businesses customer segment, professionals customer segment or other similar segments in which we operate, we refer specifically to the markets for ERP and business management software for micro and small businesses, mid-market businesses and professionals (i.e. labor advisors, accountants and fiscal consultants), respectively. The share in certain segments as well as similar data included in this Offering Memorandum do not include products and services for certain specific industries. Shares for (i) the ERP and business management software market is estimated based on the number of seats, that is the number of users within each customer, and (ii) the e-invoicing market is estimated based on the number of e-invoices sent to the Italian Revenue Agency’s exchange system through our TeamSystem Digital platform out of the total number of e-invoices sent to the Italian Revenue Agency in 2023 by SMEs, micro B2B-oriented businesses. The global consulting company report content described in this Offering Memorandum (the “Global Consulting

Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: We are the leading provider of cloud-based mission critical ERP, financial management system (“FMS”) and e-invoicing software for micro, small and mid-market businesses as well as professional customers in Italy, with a growing international presence, including in Spain and Turkey. Our mission is to improve the competitiveness of our customers, supporting them with the digitalization and automation of their internal and external business processes through our premium cloud-based product offering and solutions which also connect businesses, professionals and public administration organizations. Our products include software solutions for the core business processes of accountants and labor consultants (such as the provision of tax and accounting advice and payroll services) and a suite of financial management, accounting management, enterprise asset management, human capital management, production and supply chain management, administration and invoicing management and customer management software solutions, bolstered by artificial intelligence (“AI”) and data analysis tools, for micro, small and mid-market businesses. We also offer on-premise solutions providing assistance and software maintenance services for all our products, nonetheless we actively support and transition our customers to cloud and SaaS native solutions, through a dual-track operating model to assist them in their transformation journey. Across industries, we embrace customer demand for digitalization solutions for business processes that, until recently, had not been automated or digitalized. Customers who utilize our integrated cloud-based solutions may digitally execute a variety of tasks, such as invoicing, document signing and other business management processes, which allows them to reduce their overall expenses and increase their business efficiency. Our easy-to-use integrated cloud-based software products have also enabled us to target micro business customers who have historically not utilized higher-functionality and more complex on premise business management software, and drive the digitalization shift for core business management processes. We believe we have established positions across all key segments in which we operate. As of June 30, 2023, we held an approximately 30% share in the small and mid-market businesses customer segment and more than 30% share in the professionals customer segment, in each case in Italy, based on number of seats (IDC). In addition, according to an analysis conducted by a global consulting company in the first half of 2023 (the “Global

Subsection Title: Consulting Company Report”), we held more than 30% share in the micro businesses customer segment in
Subsubsection Text: - _In Cloud. Our In Cloud product line consists of cloud-based solutions tailored for micro and small businesses, enabling them to digitalize core processes such as invoicing, accounting, and customer relationship management, designed to provide a single point of contact, addressing their distinct operational needs. Our most successful software in this product line is Fatture in Cloud. - _Studio Cloud. Our Studio Cloud product line consists of mission-critical, comprehensive and scalable solutions for professionals, including accountants, law firms and CAFs. It integrates functionalities like financial statement management, payroll, and tax management into a single product suite. - _Enterprise Cloud. Our Enterprise Cloud product line provides a full suite of customizable ERP solutions designed to support mid-sized companies in their digital transformation journey. Such product line includes modules for digital accounting, cash management, inventory management and procurement and industry-specific features that cater to the unique needs of target segments, such as construction and fashion.

Subsection Title: Consulting Company Report”), we held more than 30% share in the micro businesses customer segment in
Subsubsection Text: - _Digital Invoice. Our Digital Invoice product line is a cornerstone of our ERP and FMS platforms, offering a secure solution for creating, sending, receiving, and storing electronic invoices. It ensures full compliance with Italian regulatory frameworks, thereby playing a pivotal role in the rapidly evolving digital landscape, offering a comprehensive and integrated approach to managing daily invoicing tasks. - _Digital Finance. Our Digital Finance product line offers a comprehensive suite of solutions for digital payment, credit and rating services, enhancing working capital management and simplifying payment processes for SMBs and larger enterprises. - _Extended CRM. Our Extended CRM product line provides advanced tools for our small and mid-market customers to streamline their relationship management, marketing automation and e-commerce integration, helping businesses scale their operations and enhancing customer engagement. Extended CRM fully integrates with our ERP and FMS software, creating a unified, multi-channel and efficient business management ecosystem. ----- - _HR Solutions. Our HR Solutions product line offers an integrated suite of digital tools for payroll and human resources management, catering to micro-small companies, SMBs, large enterprises, accountants and labor consultants. HR Solutions features full integration with our ERP and FMS software, ensuring streamlined operations and data consistency. - _Trust Services. Our Trust Services product line enables secure, compliant digital operations through digital signatures, archiving and SPID access. Trust Services features full integration with our ERP and FMS software, ensuring streamlined operations and data consistency. Our total revenues from cross-selling platforms, which include most of our horizontal solutions (Digital Finance, Extended CRM, HR Solutions and Trust Services) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 accounted for €97.0 million. In order to provide our customers with best-in-class solutions to facilitate the digitalization of their processes, we have been integrating AI solutions and tools across our entire product suite to enhance automation, predictive capabilities and overall efficiency, thereby elevating customer experience and increasing productivity. Moreover, we have continuously evolved our product suite and underlying technologies. Based on our innovative Software-as-a-Service (“SaaS”) platform, we have developed a comprehensive set of cloud-based software products that allowed us to penetrate the large segment of micro and small businesses customers in Italy, which have not historically utilized on premise software solutions mainly due to their relative complexity, enabling us to maintain a strong leadership position among accountants and mid-sized business customer. In addition, due to our technologically advanced and fully developed and integrated suite of digital products such as HR, Digital Signature, Digital Finance solutions, authentication, customer analytics and relationship management, we believe we are better positioned than our competitors to exploit the growing demand for digitalization solutions in both our Italian and international relevant sectors. We expect that the demand for digitalization solutions will continue to grow, driven by supportive regulations and incentives, as well as the need for customers to adapt to a changing environment that demands operational efficiency and automation. For example, in Italy we foresee potential opportunities from the upcoming tax reform on e-receipts which is expected to extend further than the current einvoicing prescribed for business-to-business relationships. At an international level, we plan to benefit from the mandatory e-invoicing adoption in both Spain and Turkey. Set forth below is a graphic representing the interaction among our business units, product lines and target customers. _Source: Management analysis._ -----

Subsection Title: Consulting Company Report”), we held more than 30% share in the micro businesses customer segment in
Subsubsection Text: terms of value over the same period. As of June 30, 2023, we had a growing or established presence in the sectors in which we operate, including Digital Finance, human capital management (“HCM”), payroll and industryspecific sectors, with shares of up to 22% in some of these segments. Moreover, as of June 30, 2023, our strategic operations and leadership enabled us to achieve a share of approximately 4% in Spain and approximately 14% in Turkey, based on revenue generated within these sectors divided by the estimated SAM of each sector and expressed as a percentage thereof, thus successfully establishing our presence in these growing sectors. We offer our products and services through six main business units: - Professional Solutions. Our Professional Solutions business unit includes software for professionals, including accountants, and labor consultants, including accounting, payroll, billing and compliance tools. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Professional Solutions business unit accounted for 28.3% of our total revenue. - Micro Solutions. Our Micro Solutions business unit includes cloud-based products designed for micro and small business customers (0-9 employees and 10-49 employees, respectively), such as Fatture in Cloud, Contabilità in Cloud and Cassa in Cloud. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Micro Solutions business unit accounted for 27.2% of our total revenue. - Enterprise Solutions. Our Enterprise Solutions business unit includes ERP and FMS software for midmarket business customers (10-500 employees), including administration, finance, human resources, sales, supply chain management and production. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 our Enterprise Solutions business unit accounted for 22.0% of our total revenue. ----- - Market Specific Solutions. Our Market Specific Solutions business unit includes products and services designed to address the needs of customers in specific industries, such as, among others, mechanical and manufacturing, construction, CAF/public sectors and legal, and the needs for all business sizes from micro to mid-size. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Market Specific Solutions business unit accounted for 12.9% of our total revenue. - Cross Segment Product Solutions. Our Cross Segment Product Solutions offers HR and Trust solutions, including digital signature, archive and digital identity services, which are fully integrated with our ERP systems. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Cross Segment Product Solutions business unit accounted for 6.8% of our total revenue. - Digital Finance Solutions. Our Digital Finance Solutions business unit includes digital financial valueadded services designed to streamline financial operations of our customers and address their needs, such as rating services, credit management and digital payment solutions. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Digital Finance Solutions business unit accounted for 2.8% of our total revenue. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated total revenue and Adjusted EBITDA of €778.7 million (compared to €423 million for the year ended December 31, 2020) and €334.8 million (compared to €209 million for the year ended December 31, 2020), respectively. The following chart sets forth our total revenue breakdown by business unit for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated 83.5% of our total revenue from recurring sources, which are primarily related to annual software assistance and maintenance contracts, annual subscription contracts, annual fees from our multi-year contracts with VARs and fees from temporary annual licenses (licenze _temporanee annuali) that we sell to our customers whenever the Italian government introduces a new regulatory_ obligation (e.g., a new tax digital reporting obligation or tax payment) that requires a dedicated feature to be added to our software products (we refer to such temporary annual licenses as “Regulatory LTAs”). We believe that our technology leadership, significant and ongoing expansion of our cloud-based solutions, the mission-critical nature of our products and the overall willingness of our customers to renew their contracts have contributed, and will continue to contribute, to our high annual subscription contracts and renewal rates. Most of our products are deeply integrated into our end-customers’ IT systems and business processes, and their replacement is normally a complicated, time-consuming and expensive process, requiring extensive training for users. In addition, our digital and cloud-based solutions platform, Digital Invoice, designed to operate across all our digital products, is integrated with all our ERP solutions and allows our customers to digitally send, receive, register and store electronic invoices from and to private customers, companies, public entities, banks and external accountants and to send tax filings to the relevant tax authorities electronically. Our three key customer groups are micro and small businesses, mid-market businesses and professionals, which are located both in Italy and abroad. Our end-customer base, including VAR’s end-customers, increased from approximately 88,000 as of December 31, 2009 to approximately 2.1 million as of December 31, 2023. Of this total figure, approximately 87.7% are micro and small businesses, approximately 8.6% are mid-market businesses and approximately 3.7% are professionals. Our large and diverse customer base is highly fragmented and diversified in terms of size and geography. As of December 31, 2023, we had approximately 276 thousand customers outside of Italy, our ten largest customers generated 5.0% of our total revenue, while our 50 largest customers and 200 largest customers generated 10.4% and 15.3%, respectively. Our customer base is also spread across a variety of industries, including accountancy, labor advisory, manufacturing, industrial, construction, wellness, hospitality, fashion, retail, distribution, food and beverage, legal and other professional services sectors. ----- We have strategically internalized our VARs to establish stronger and more direct relationships with our customer base. This approach allows us to provide personalized and seamless services, enhancing customer satisfaction and loyalty. Such approach also supports our upselling initiatives, offering tailored solutions that meet the evolving needs of our clients and aiding them in the continuing transition to cloud solutions. Through these efforts, we ensure our clients benefit from the latest technological advancements while maintaining our competitive edge in the field. In furtherance of our internalization strategy, we have continued to pursue a series of bolt-on acquisitions to bolster our competitive position, expand our product offerings and continue our international expansion. In recent years, we expanded into Spain by acquiring a controlling interest in the Spanish start-up Billin and consolidated our presence in the country by acquiring Software del Sol. In 2023, we further expanded our portfolio with acquisitions such as Acumbamail and Aplifisa, and entered the Turkish sector by acquiring the Mikro group. Lastly, in 2024, we entered into an acquisition agreement with the French ERP software provider to continue expand our presence outside of Italy. Our acquisitions have contributed positively to our revenue growth, product and business mix diversification. This acquisition strategy is key to our growth plan, driving sustained expansion and reinforcing our leadership in the sector. We implemented a series of nominal price increases across our customer segments. In the micro and small businesses customer segment, prices were raised by a total of 10 percentage points from 2021 to 2023, due to a high inflationary environment. In the mid-market segment, we saw a nominal price increase of 3.8 percentage points from 2020 to 2023, while in the professionals customer segment, also from 2020 to 2023, prices increased by 7.0 percentage points over the same period. During these periods, we also observed changes in customer churn. In the micro and small businesses segment, churn decreased by 0.2 percentage points between 2021 and 2023. The mid-market segment experienced a slight 0.5 percentage points churn increase between 2020 and 2023, and in the professionals customer segment, churn decreased by 1.8 percentage points from 2020 to 2023. We divide our product offering into the following three product suites and five horizontal solutions:

Subsection Title: Our strengths
Subsubsection Title: Large and growing segments benefitting from secular digitalization with regulatory tailwinds and significant investments and expertise requirements
Subsubsection Text: We offer both cloud solutions (SaaS and IaaS) and on-premises solutions, in each case across sizeable and attractive sectors both in Italy and internationally, which offer substantial growth opportunities mainly supported by regulatory tailwinds, operational complexities and considerable initial investments. While Italy remains our core segment, we have entered the Spanish segment in 2020 in which we further consolidated our position in 2023 through the acquisition of Acumbamail and Aplifisa, as well as the Turkish segment, where in 2023 we acquired MikroGrup, a leading local player. As a leading player in the ERP sector in Italy, Spain and Turkey, we believe we are well-positioned to leverage the favorable conditions and expected trends in these countries to drive growth and expand our competitive presence. As December 31, 2023, our total serviceable addressable market (“SAM”) was estimated to be worth approximately €5.8 billion (approximately €11.5 billion of total addressable market (“TAM”)), growing at an expected CAGR of approximately 9% between 2023 and 2027. Our SAM has grown over time, from approximately €1.1 billion in 2016, to approximately €5.8 billion in 2023, due to the growth of our core Italian ERP sector and entry into new segments such as HR, Digital Finance and CRM and automation, as well as new geographies such as Spain and Turkey. Moreover, the SAM is expected to further grow to approximately €8.3 billion in 2027. These SAM figures include also the International ERP and FMS sectors in Spain and Turkey, which are estimated to be worth approximately €1.0 billion (€3.2 billion TAM) in 2023 and are expected to growth at a CAGR of approximately 12% between 2023 and 2027. Our SAM has significantly expanded via both geographic reach and product diversification, making it less susceptible to macroeconomic fluctuations. Historically, our SAM has demonstrated robust resilience through various economic cycles, including the financial crises of 2009 and 2012, as well as the COVID-19 pandemic, consistently outperforming Italy’s GDP growth. This resilience is further reinforced by our strategic focus and successful repositioning initiatives in high-growth segments, such as micro and digital finance. _Source: Global Consulting Company Report for Italy, Management analysis for Spain and Turkey, International Monetary Fund, World Economic Outlook Database, April 2024, for GDP. Note: Chart displays organic SAM growth, assuming a like-for-like perimeter year over year._ We believe there is still significant whitespace to benefit from, equivalent to the difference between SAM and TAM, which we expect to target by expanding our product offering and increasing customer reach, thereby targeting client segments currently not covered or not served with specific propositions. ----- The ERP sector in Italy, Spain, and Turkey are expected to experience continued growth, propelled by regulatorydriven tailwinds, ongoing digitalization, increased ERP software adoption across all customer sizes, and the transition to cloud-based solutions. These factors result in us being well placed to further benefit from our competitive positions and capitalize on emerging opportunities. _Italy_ In Italy, the main drivers for growth are stable demand, regulatory tailwinds, digitalization and ERP uptake, cloud transition, cybersecurity concerns and growing adoption of generative AI. We believe we are well positioned to capitalize on these trends and further expand our presence across our reference segments. The Italian ERP software market is characterized by operational complexities and considerable initial investments, particularly for international competitors, due to cultural and local commercial complexities. These include language barriers, complex payroll rules, local accounting standards (Italian GAAP), and evolving regulatory constraints in key sectors like banking, energy, and healthcare. These complexities favor local and regional players, allowing us to capitalize on our leading position in the field. Our deep knowledge of the domestic landscape and long-standing relationships with a wide cross-section of Italian customers and partners further strengthen our competitive advantage. In 2021, local and regional players held a combined 55% share, compared to an average of 25% in other EU countries, as shown in the chart below. _Source: Global Consulting Company Report._ ERP solutions are fundamental to the day-to-day activities of businesses, especially as the operations of Italian enterprises become increasingly complex. This complexity drives demand for a broader range of innovative management solutions to monitor key activities. Accounting and payroll management software remain core due to stringent Italian regulations requiring digital fiscal and labor filings. Our state-of-the-art cloud-based solutions ensure compliance with these demanding and ever-changing regulatory requirements, providing seamless support even in light of changing regulations. This allows our customers to focus on their core activities without diverting pivotal resources, ensuring stable demand and revenues for our mission-critical services. The ongoing digitalization trend in Italy is primarily driven by stringent regulatory requirements, which impose significant fiscal and administrative burdens on companies and create a strong demand for up-to-date management software that streamlines administrative functions and establishes operational complexities and considerable initial investments for new competitors. We are well-positioned to meet this demand by providing products and updates that help clients ensure regulatory compliance. Subsidies introduced over the past few years, such as the “Industry 4.0” initiative, which offers financial vouchers to promote the digitalization of SMEs and micro and small businesses, and the National Recovery and Resilience Plan (Piano Nazionale di Ripresa e Resilienza), which allocates approximately €40 billion for digitalization projects across the public sector, further incentivize digitalization in Italy. Moreover, the increasing role of European ESG regulations, such as the CSRD, is expected to drive demand for ESG software solutions. These regulations require standardized ESG disclosures from both large enterprises and SMBs, creating a need for sophisticated compliance tools. Our expertise and comprehensive product offerings ----- uniquely position us to help businesses navigate these regulatory landscapes, consolidating our competitive position leadership and expanding our customer base. The Italian market is also poised to benefit from government policies, incentives, and subsidies that promote digitalization. Italy demonstrates strong performance in the adoption of cloud services, with approximately 50% of enterprises utilizing this technology, significantly surpassing the EU average of 34%. Unlike other Mediterranean countries, Italy’s penetration rates for cloud services more closely resemble those of Nordic and Benelux economies, which have historically been more advanced in terms of digitalization. The chart below shows the digitalization rate of EU countries as of December 31, 2023[(1)]: _Source: Digital economy and society index (DESI); 2023 Indicators, data from 2021._ Note: “Enterprise with Clouds Solutions” represents enterprises which have adopted at least one of the following cloud solutions: finance or accounting software applications; ERP software applications; CRM software applications; security software applications; hosting the enterprise’s database(s); computing platform providing a hosted environment for application development, testing or deployment. Furthermore, approximately 70% of SMEs in Italy have at least a basic level of digital intensity, just above the EU average of 69%, and well above other Mediterranean countries such as France and Spain. Progress in digitalization in Italy is especially pronounced in the use of e-invoices, where Italy outperforms the European average, being one of the first countries to make e-invoices mandatory for all companies, regardless of size. This strong adoption of cloud services and digital tools underscores the readiness of Italian enterprises to embrace digital transformation, further driving demand for our advanced ERP and FMS solutions. _Source: Digital economy and society index (DESI) 2023 Indicators, data from 2022. The digital intensity score is based on counting how many of twelve selected technologies are used by enterprises. A basic level requires usage of at least four technologies._ Despite the above, the Italian market is considered to be still at the early stages of its digital transformation journey. While it has achieved a nearly 100% adoption rate for e-invoicing software across companies of all sizes, driven by government regulations, there remain substantial growth opportunities for ERP, CRM and business ----- intelligence software, especially among micro and small-sized businesses where the adoption rate is currently below 30%. The chart below shows the software adoption rate by company size as of December 31, 2023 _Source: ISTAT report imprese 2023._ Lastly, within the global cloud market, the ERP sector is less penetrated than other functional markets. Adoption of cloud-based ERP software has been slower compared to financial applications and performance software, which remain predominantly on-premise. This contrasts with the CRM and HCM sectors, where the transition to cloudbased technology has been quicker. The slower adoption rate of ERP systems is due to their mission-critical nature and the increased need for customization compared to CRM and HCM systems. However, cloud adoption in the Italian ERP sector has been steadily increasing, with penetration expected to reach approximately 48% of the market in 2023 and continue to rise thereafter. We believe this additional trend presents a significant opportunity for us to expand our cloud-based ERP offerings and capture a growing share. The ever-increasing demand for cybersecurity is also a significant growth driver, with cyber attacks rising dramatically across all industries. In 2022, global cyber attacks increased by 21.5% compared to 2021, and Italy saw a staggering 170% increase, making it the fourth most targeted country. Many attacks result from human error, highlighting the need for better technology training and simple software solutions. With low current SMB adoption of cybersecurity software, there is a substantial growth opportunity for products dedicated to cyber risks mitigation. We believe the EU Cybersecurity SMB software TAM, which was worth approximately €12 billion in 2022, is expected to grow by 12% between 2022 and 2024. By offering and integrating robust cybersecurity features into our ERP and FMS solutions, we can enhance our value proposition and consolidated our position within the sector. Furthermore, the availability of new technology, such as advanced machine learning and generative AI, is a crucial growth driver. The AI sector, which includes software, hardware, and services, is projected to grow at a CAGR of 18% between 2020 and 2025, with software being the dominant segment. Success in the ERP space will depend on leveraging generative AI for internal efficiency and integrating it into customer solutions. In Italy, AI awareness is increasing, with many professionals recognizing it as a key trend and considering AI products to enhance efficiency and productivity. Our significant investments in Data and AI position us to meet our customers’ evolving needs, offering advanced AI-infused business applications that drive efficiency and productivity, thereby strengthening our competitive edge. _Spain_ We believe that, similar to Italy, growth in the Spanish ERP sector is driven by regulatory changes, increasing digitalization, and the transition to cloud-based solutions. Regulation in Spain plays an active role in sustaining our sector dynamics. Key regulatory trends expected to positively impact the ERP sector in Spain include grants and subsidies, tax level changes, accounting software standard enforcement, and mandatory e-invoicing. Spain is making notable progress in digital technology integration, particularly through initiatives targeting the digitalization of SMEs and the self-employed. These efforts are driving the growth in the ERP sector and increasing the demand for advanced accounting software due to potential fiscal complexities from ongoing tax rate debates and heightened standards following recent data breaches. The shift from voluntary to mandatory einvoicing, set to be compulsory for small and micro-enterprises by 2026 and for larger enterprises by 2024, is a key growth driver. Despite SMEs’ digitalization levels being slightly below the EU average, the Spanish government’s investments in digitalization present significant growth opportunities, not only enhancing SMEs’ ----- capabilities but also impacting ICT specialists, infrastructure, and digital public services. Additionally, measures to boost cloud computing adoption are underway, addressing the current lag behind the European average. Key growth drivers in Spain over the next few years include strong upsell and cross-sell opportunities, with a significant increase in average revenue per customer expected, and a rapid shift to cloud-based services. Cloud penetration is expected to grow substantially across segments, including accountants and small to mid-sized companies. With a deep understanding of the market and a comprehensive suite of ERP and FMS solutions, we believed we are strategically positioned to harness these trends, meeting the evolving needs of the Spanish segment. _Turkey_ Similar to Italy and Spain, growth in the Turkish ERP sector is expected to be driven by regulatory changes and increased digitalization. The Turkish government has worked towards combating the shadow economy by establishing online systems for real-time tracking and auditing. Key initiatives such as e-integration, mandatory online salary payments, and enhanced auditing systems are expected to sustain growth within the ERP sector. Current regulations require companies with a certain level of turnover to comply with e-invoicing regulations, and the inflationary environment in Turkey is likely to increase the number of companies falling within this threshold, therefore expanding the sector.

Subsection Title: Our strengths
Subsubsection Title: Long-standing leadership position with a strong track record of growth in targeted customer segments
Subsubsection Text: We believe we have achieved a leading position across our customer segments, product offering and key geographies. In terms of customers, our leading position spans across the Italian micro and small businesses customer segment (“Micro”), in terms of value, which mainly refers to FMS solutions for micro enterprise (including e-invoicing, accounting software and POS systems), mid-market business customer segment (“Enterprise”) in terms of number of seats, which refer to the segment for ERP software for SMEs, and professional customer segment (“Professional”), in terms of number of seats, which comprises accountants and labor and tax advisors. According to the Global Consulting Company Report, as of June 30, 2023, we held more than 30% share in Italy based on market value in the Micro business customer segment. According to IDC, we held a share based on numbers of seats of approximately 30% (compared to an approximately 23% combined share of our three closest competitors) and more than 30% (compared to an approximately 44% combined share of our three closest competitors) in the Italian Enterprise and Professional customer segments, respectively, as of the same date. Our leading position in Italy across our customer segments is the result of many years of developing our proprietary software through significant investment, which has established our reputation for high-quality and reliable products and services in such segments. Since our early entry in the Micro customer segment in 2019, we have built a strong customer base and achieved high client satisfaction, enabling us to grow our share above 30% in terms number of seats between 2019 and the first half of 2023 (Global Consulting Company Report). Our comprehensive offering of innovative software solutions has allowed us to navigate the evolving Italian regulatory environment and establish our leadership position within this fragmented sector. Our extensive product suite not only solidifies our share within our reference segments but also enhances customer loyalty and engagement. As a result, our closest top three competitors in this segment held a collective estimated share in the sector of approximately 26.0% as of June 30, 2023, underscoring our established leadership and the effectiveness of our first-mover advantage (Global Consulting Company Report). In the Enterprise customer segment, we have achieved a clear leadership position, underpinned by our mission to support SMEs in their digital transformation and to improve their efficiency and competitiveness while ensuring compliance with the Italian regulatory framework. Our ability to offer a wide range of services has enabled us to benefit from significant economies of scale. Our integrated and customizable platform of solutions allow us to address the needs of companies across selected verticals, reinforcing our leadership and driving sustained growth. The Professional customer segment is relatively more stable and mature compared to other segments. Our leadership in this segment, which we have maintained since 2019, is underpinned by superior brand recognition, supported by a loyal customer base and delivery of high-quality, reliable and integrated software solutions, which ensures that we remain the preferred choice for professional customers, further consolidating our competitive position. ----- In terms of product offering, we believe to have achieved a promising position in key product segments such as Digital Finance, human resources solutions and certain industry-specific segments. In particular, in the Digital Finance segment we see significant opportunities to further expand our product offerings and increase our competitive presence. Holding less than 1% share in 2023, as a percentage of SAM, there is a high potential for revenue generation in the Digital Finance segment. In the human resources solutions segment, which encompasses HCM and payroll software, we achieved an approximately 7% share in the HCM segment, and an approximately 22% share in the payroll segment, in each case as of June 30, 2023. Furthermore, as of June 30, 2023, we held an approximately 22% share for CAD/CAM solutions and an approximately 7% for Extended CRM and marketing automation. With regards to our geographic sector, we believe we are a leading player in Italy in the ERP sector. In addition, we also operate in attractive segments outside of Italy. Our international expansion began in 2020 with acquisitions in Spain, followed by Turkey in 2022. These strategic moves have significantly increased our presence and influence in these key segments. For our international segment, mainly comprising ERP software solutions for Spain and Turkey, the SAM and TAM amounted to approximately €1.0 billion and approximately €3.2 billion, respectively, as of June 30, 2023. Our strategic operations and experienced leadership enabled us to achieve a share of approximately 4% in Spain, which increased from approximately 2% in 2020, and an approximately 14% share in Turkey, based on revenue generated within these segments divided by the estimated SAM of each segment and expressed as a percentage thereof for the same period. These results underscore our rapid development of influence and competitive edge in these segments.

Subsection Title: Our strengths
Subsubsection Title: Comprehensive product suite for SMBs and professionals enabling cross-sell, up-sell, and broader ecosystem benefits
Subsubsection Text: Our product offering is carefully designed to cater to the diverse requirements of our customers, providing cloudbased solutions that are customized for businesses of different sizes and needs. Our offering includes, among others, specialized state-of-the-art features that increase operational efficiency and advanced analytics, bolstered by AI tools and capabilities. Our integrated cloud-based offering enables customer collaboration and allows us to implement cross-selling initiatives for various solutions. As indicated below, certain of our products within our comprehensive offering are dedicated to specific clusters of customers, while certain others are typically available for our entire customer platform. _Source: Management analysis._ Our range of cloud products, part of an integrated platform and vertical solutions, empowers customers to digitalize core processes such as quoting, billing, managing customer relationships and streamlining business monitoring. These offerings feature an intuitive, user-friendly interface, regularly enhanced through updates to ----- ensure reliability, efficiency and ease of use. This continuous improvement cycle keeps our solutions at the forefront of technological advancements, providing customers with cutting-edge tools to stay competitive while ensuring compliance with applicable laws. This translates into up-selling opportunities and increased high-quality revenues, as most of our solutions generate recurring revenues. Our leading integrated cloud application suite has enabled us to secure a substantial customer base, which we aim to further expand by exploiting new opportunities, such as the ongoing digitalization and regulatory tailwinds as well as through cross-selling initiatives. Most of our products and services are offered across our micro and small businesses, professional and mid-market businesses customer segments. A notable example is our Digital Invoice solution. This mission-critical solution is essential for companies adopting e-invoicing, driven by regulatory mandates. In 2023, our Digital Invoice solution supported over 480 million invoices, representing an aggregate value of approximately €1,050 billion and assisted around 2.0 million customers with Digital Invoice applications. Our Digital Invoice applications offer security and reliability, crucial for managing daily invoicing digitally. We have been successful at up-selling our products and expanding our customer base through value-added solutions. In addition, we benefit from our customer base beyond invoicing and accounting to cross-sell our Digital Finance, CRM in Cloud, HR and Trust solutions, which generated approximately €100 million in revenues for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We believe these solutions have further opportunity to expand within our customer base as our customer product penetration is below approximately 4%. This holistic approach offered to companies and accountants in a user-friendly and cost-efficient manner enhances customer satisfaction, retention and lifetime value. Furthermore, our SaaS platform integrates advanced analytics and AI capabilities, positioning us well to leverage data monetization and AI as key drivers for growth and differentiation. By expanding our offerings with new datacentric products, including tools for aggregated data and benchmarking, we have implemented data-driven approaches to enhance our business operations and product offerings.
