Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key trends and growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the Italian ERP sector is characterized by following key trends and growth drivers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Operational complexities and considerable initial investments
Subsubsection Text: The Italian ERP sector is a defensive market for existing incumbents. Regulatory complexity in Italy and the frequency of regulatory changes are a key characteristic of the Italian market and create operational complexities and considerable initial investments. These are further consolidated by the complexity of both tax returns and payroll processes in Italy. As such, software providers need to have a deep and ever-evolving understanding of the local market. Furthermore, an understanding of the Italian language, as well as of Italian GAAP and IFRS reporting standards is required. As a result of these complexities and requirements unique to the Italian market, unlike in other countries, in Italy, the largest software providers are all domestic. ----- _Source: Analysis based on IDC data._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Stability of demand for ERP solutions due to mission critical nature of services
Subsubsection Text: We believe ERP solutions are fundamental to the day-to-day activities of a business. The operations of Italian enterprises have become increasingly complex which has driven demand for a broader range of innovative management solutions used to monitor key company activities; at the same time, accounting and payroll management software solutions are core activities for professionals and are particularly relevant in Italy, as Italian regulations require fiscal and labor filings to be submitted digitally to the relevant authorities. We believe such complexity will continue to increase and will continue to drive demand for ERP products and business software and services.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory driven adoption
Subsubsection Text: Regulation in Italy continues to play an active role in sustaining our addressable market growth. Regulatory complexity, frequent regulation changes, the digitalization of Public Administration and government subsidies to incentivize digitalization in Italy are all key market growth drivers. Regulation complexity and frequent changes demand for constantly updated management software, which creates both high entry barriers to the Italian market but also positive tailwinds for us, as we can continue servicing our clients’ needs by providing products and updates to help them ensure regulatory compliance. - Framework complexity: Regulatory frameworks across tax, accounting, and payroll requirements are highly complex in Italy. For example, from a tax perspective, there is an objective complexity of fiscal and administrative requirements (e.g. the tax return form has more fields in comparison to the UK equivalent form). From a payroll perspective, Italy is ranked the fourth most complex country for payroll in Alight’s 2023 Global Complexity index. The country’s complexity is driven by court-ordered deductions, the type of mandatory reporting required and the frequency of reporting to the government. This complexity results in a requirement for highly localized software which is capable of interfacing with government protocol. - Frequent regulatory changes: Beyond the complexity of the system, substantial regulatory changes are also very frequent in Italy. Compared with other European countries, Italy has seen the most frequent changes to tax regulation, with more than 110 changes over the past three years: ----- _Source: European Commission._ Digitalization of the Public Administration and subsidies can create direct and indirect positive impacts in incentivizing adoption of digital tools and helping to close the digital gap. - Public Administration digitalization: Recent effort to digitalize Public Administration (“PA”) to improve PA-enterprises efficiency and cut PA costs in Italy. This has incentivized the adoption of digital tools and software among public bodies to streamline and improve the procurement of supplies and services work. - Subsidies: Subsidies introduced over the past few years to incentivize digitalization in Italy (e.g. Industria 4.0, PNRR) further foster the demand for software in Italy. Italy has taken several initiatives to stimulate digitization. For example, The National Recovery and Resilience Plan (PNRR – with an approximate €40 billion budget dedicated to digitalization projects across the public sector) has provided a significant boost by directing investment toward the digitization of SMEs. We expect European regulation related to ESG and non-financial reporting to also play an increasing role in the market evolution. ESG software is designed to solve for the complexities associated with ESG compliance (from ESG data collection, to ESG risk management and ESG reporting). Regulation is evolving and becoming increasingly prescriptive, and companies are forced to navigate different rules and frameworks. Crucially, the EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) should be made effective in July 2024 and will require the disclosure of standardized ESG topics by more than 50,000 companies in the EU. While the CSRD’s scope is initially limited to larger enterprises, it is important to note that implementation across SMBs will occur via a phased approach after July 2024, and many SMBs are nonetheless already indirectly impacted today and required to comply with the regulation. A first example of this indirect impact is that large enterprises are called to report on the sustainability of their supply chain. As such, any SMB in the ecosystem of a larger enterprise is expected to be impacted as their customers (the larger enterprise) will require the SMBs in their supply chain to report according to sustainability metrics, which they can in turn report on. Furthermore, all enterprises, including SMBs, competing for any government request for proposal (“RfP”) and contract are also evermore required to report certain ESG metrics, and being able to provide the required ESG questionnaires is becoming mandatory to win the contracts, thus forcing all enterprises who do business with the government to adopt ESG reporting tools too. Additionally, we believe that beyond regulatory-driven adoption, enterprises of all sizes are increasingly incentivized to adopt ESG reporting (and therefore ESG software) because it drives operational improvements, in the form of improved access to financing, and to better customer demand. From a financing perspective, sustainable companies have access to more financing options such as sustainability-linked loans and bonds. Moreover, they have access to better financing options, as banks are introducing more sophisticated ESG disclosure requirements in financing processes. From a customer demand perspective, customers are increasingly ----- demanding more sophisticated corporate social responsibility (“CSR”) policies, and multiple market studies show that there is a performance gap between companies which implement CSR policies and those who do not, as consumers and companies are more likely to buy from the former, rather than the latter. ESG reporting requirements are therefore expected to play an increasing role in the SMB market and drive demand for ESG software solutions that support companies in meeting compliance requirements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Ongoing Digitalization and ERP uptake
Subsubsection Text: There have been significant advances in digital infrastructure in Italy in recent years and there are indicators underpinning the potential for continued growth. Italy appears to be lagging behind other European Countries in terms of Digitalization more generally, ranking below the EU average in the DESI 2022 index. That said, the DESI index is an aggregation of countries’ ranking across various dimensions, namely: Human Capital, Connectivity, Integration of Digital Technology, and Digital Public Services dimension. Crucially, however, the Integration of Digital Technology dimension is the most relevant to our market of operation. The Integration of Digital Technology dimension aims to capture the use of technology by Enterprises, analyzing, amongst other indicators, (i) the use of Cloud services and (ii) the proportion of SMEs with at least a basic level of digital intensity. Under this lens, Italy performs well in comparison to other European countries. Italy performs well in the uptake of cloud services, with approximately 50% of enterprises using this technology (well above the EU average of 34%). Unlike other Mediterranean countries, Italy’s penetration rates for cloud services more closely resemble Nordic and Benelux economies, the latter having historically been far more advanced in terms of digitalization. Both business to government (“B2G”) and business to business (“B2B”) einvoicing is compulsory in Italy, and this has contributed significantly to the adoption of cloud accounting, especially in the low end of the market where companies have adopted cloud native solutions. However, a sizeable opportunity remains as the lower end of the market is still rather underpenetrated in terms of overall ERP adoption, and on the other hand the higher end of the market is continuing its transition to the cloud. _Source: Digital economy and society index (DESI); 2023 Indicators, data from 2021. (1) At least one of the following: finance or accounting software applications; enterprise resource planning (ERP) software applications; customer relationship management (CRM) software applications; security software applications; hosting the enterprise’s database(s); computing platform providing a hosted environment for application development, testing or deployment._ Furthermore, approximately 70% of SMEs in Italy have at least a basic level of digital intensity, just above the EU average of 69%, and well above other Mediterranean countries such as France and Spain. As detailed below, progress in digitalization in Italy is especially pronounced in the use of e-invoices, where Italy outperforms the European average, being one of the first country to make e-invoices mandatory for all companies (regardless of company size). ----- _Source: Digital economy and society index (DESI) 2023 Indicators, data from 2022. The digital intensity score is based on counting how many out of 12 selected technologies are used by enterprises. A basic level requires usage of at least 4 technologies._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Ongoing Digitalization and ERP uptake
Subsubsection Title: Digitalization & ERP uptake by Enterprise size
Subsubsection Text: Italian SME businesses (<250 employees) make up approximately 99% of all businesses, of which approximately 95% are micro businesses with 0-9 employees. In terms of software adoption by company size, while the adoption of solutions for e-invoicing is very high (97%+ across the board) given the introduction of mandatory e-invoicing in Italy, the adoption of more advanced software solutions in Italy diverges by company size. _Source: Istat report imprese 2023._ - Small businesses (10-49 employees): while 97% utilize an e-invoicing software, only 39% have an ERP software and only 17% utilize a CRM software. Continued digitalization and ERP adoption is driven by shifts and transformation of SME operating models that require more advanced instruments to attract and retain customers, manage the rapid growth in online demand, streamline key processes (for example tax, accounting, bookkeeping, invoicing, budgeting, estimates, inventories, POS, accounting, etc.) via digital platform, increase productivity and adapt to work from home (“WFH”) arrangements with access to collaboration tools. ----- - Mid-market (50-249 employees): the mid-market benefits from higher percentages of ERP adoption (61% for 50-99 employees and 72% for 100-249 employees), however i) the adoption of more advanced modules is still low (e.g. for CRM: 26% for 50-99 employees and 36% for 100-249 employees, for business intelligence: 33% for 50-99 employees and 46% for 100-249 employees), which means there is expected to be more space to cross-sell additional modules, and ii) existing solutions tend to be outdated, so there is an upgrade cycle which is expected to take place and will likely be done via cloud solutions. Demand for additional modules is expected to be driven by the increasing need of companies of digitize and automatize operations and embed data and AI within their operating model.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Ongoing transition to cloud
Subsubsection Title: Italian ERP sector by Delivery Model (%)
Subsubsection Text: _Source: Global Consulting Company Report._ Cloud solutions generally provide additional benefits to customers compared to on-premise solutions, such as: (i) lower total costs of ownership, eliminating perpetual license costs and hardware/infrastructure costs (which are typical of on premise installation) and maintaining only the annual subscription costs for using the software and receiving maintenance and assistance services; (ii) quicker and cheaper implementation; (iii) more rapid software development cycles and quicker update roll-outs, with no interventions at customers’ sites needed, (iv) a more streamlined IT operating model (requiring a lower number of suppliers, and with a single, focal, contact point for any issues, (v) increased ease of integration; (vi) offer a 360° customer view, (vii) more cost effective scalability; and (viii) faster time to market. Cloud-based solutions represent a significant change in how software companies are bringing their solutions to market and have the potential to significantly impact the operation of companies’ IT infrastructures. In particular, cloud-based solutions allow smaller companies to benefit from sophisticated applications that have traditionally been utilized only by larger organizations, as historically, the implementation cost and the level of IT support required to run on premise applications efficiently prevented smaller companies from using sophisticated software. Cloud-based solutions can therefore reduce such barriers to usage, enable software houses to develop more easy-to-use solutions and allow an increasing number of businesses to streamline and simplify their IT ----- infrastructures and application deployment, also allowing micro and small businesses to purchase and utilize simple ERP solutions targeted to their needs. Furthermore, cloud technology generally enables companies to integrate third party solutions and analytics solutions more easily than via traditional on-premise offerings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Ongoing transition to cloud
Subsubsection Text: Within the global cloud market, the ERP sector is less penetrated than other functional markets. The adoption of cloud-based software has been slower with respect to financial applications and performance software, which are still predominantly on-premise technologies, as compared to the CRM and human capital management (“HCM”) sectors, where the transition to cloud-based technology has been quicker. The slower adoption rate of ERP systems is due to the mission-critical nature of ERP as well as the increased need for customization versus CRM and HCM systems. However, cloud adoption in the Italian ERP sector has been steadily increasing over recent years, with penetration expected to reach approximately 48% of the market in 2023 and to continue to increase thereafter.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Cybersecurity Demand
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the increasing demand for cybersecurity is also an important growth driver in our reference market. Cybersecurity is a global risk which impacts all industries. The frequency of cyber attacks has increased significantly in recent years, as such the demand for software solutions is growing. 2022 saw 21.5% more cases of cyber security attacks globally in comparison to 2021 (Source: Rapporto Clusit 2023). The issue is particularly strong in Italy: on a national level, Italy is the fourth country by number of attacks, behind the US, Germany, and France (Source: ENISA Threat Landscape for Ransomware Attacks, 2022), and Italy saw approximately 170% more cases of cyber attacks in 2022 than 2021 (in comparison to the global average of 21.5%). Cyber attacks are generally costly for companies to incur, yet are from our perspective often easily avoidable. We believe that approximately 90% of attacks are a result of human error due to lack of adequate technology training. As current SMB adoption of cybersecurity software is very low, and, given the ubiquitous threat level, demand for simple software solutions is on the rise. We thus believe there remains a big market opportunity to reduce cyber risks and attacks for SMBs. We believe the EU Cybersecurity SMB software TAM to be worth approximately €12 billion (as of 2022). Supported by the increase in attacks, and the SMB demand for cybersecurity software products, the EU cybersecurity SMB TAM market is expected to grow 12% between 2022 and 2024 (Source: Management).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Emerging Technology – Generative AI
Subsubsection Text: We believe that, similarly to Italy, growth in the Spanish ERP sector is also driven by regulatory changes, increasing digitalization and transition to cloud. _Regulatory driven adoption_ Regulation in Spain plays an active role in sustaining our addressable market dynamics. Regulatory changes, such as grants and subsidies, tax level changes, accounting software standard enforcement, and e-invoicing are expected to have a positive impact on the ERP sector in Spain. - Digitalization grants: There have been continued efforts to improve enterprises’ digitalization in Spain – the country has made strong progress on the integration of digital technology front. Spain has launched: 1) the Kit Digital initiative (budget: €3 billion) to promote scalable, high-impact, and publicprivate collaboration mechanisms to accelerate the digitalization of SMEs (with a focus on microenterprises) and the self-employed; and 2) the Agents of Change programme (budget: €300 million), ----- which aims to provide SMEs with grants to hire digital transformation experts. These governmental initiatives foster the implementation and development of digital transformation solutions and as a result, we expect these to boost the growth of the ERP sector. - Tax level changes: Ongoing political debates surrounding tax rate changes may result in beneficial market trends, and any resulting changes to tax rates could increase complexity of the fiscal system and processes. Increased complexity could increase the demand for deep and local market expertise, as well as for accounting software solutions. - Accounting software standards enforcement: the multitude of recent data breach incidents may result in higher standards for accounting software’s protection of user data and privacy. Enforcement of stricter standards could drive demand for continued software upgrades, supporting market dynamics and growth. - Mandatory e-invoicing: a shift from voluntary to mandatory e-invoicing could be a key growth driver in the Spanish ERP sector, increasing demand for Software accounting solutions. B2B e-invoicing is expected to be made mandatory for small and micro-enterprises in 2026, and in July 2024 for those with turnover exceeding €8 million. _Enterprise digitalization & Cloud_ SMEs are particularly relevant in Spain, where almost 2.7 million SMEs (over 99.9% of the total) contributed 58% of total value added (€288 billion) and employed 8.5 million people (68% of the total workforce) in 2020 (Source: DESI 2023 & Eurostat). However, SME digitalization appears to be slightly below the EU average, with Spain registering 67.5% of SMEs with at least a basic level of digital intensity, in comparison to the European average of 69% (as detailed in the DESI chart above). The Spanish government is continuing to invest to improve enterprises’ digitalization levels in Spain, where there remains ample growth opportunities. Reforms and investments to improve scalability and digitalization of SMEs may not only have a direct effect on SMEs’ basic and advanced digitalization but may also have an indirect multiplier impact on other dimensions and targets (e.g. the number and quality of ICT specialists, infrastructure, and digital public services) and the overall Spanish economy. The share of SMEs with at least a basic level of digital intensity remains just below the EU average, and there remains ample opportunity for growth. Spain is currently also implementing several measures to increase the number of enterprises taking up cloud computing as Spain currently lags the European average for adoption of cloud computing amongst enterprises, with Spain at 27% of enterprises with cloud computing services of sophisticated or intermediate level in contrast to the European average of 34% (as detailed in the DESI chart above). In 2022, under Spain’s RRP, the country launched the UNICO I+D Cloud programme, which provides grants to support innovative cloud computing projects in public research centers and foundations as well as public universities. In the context of the IPCEI on Next Generation Cloud Infrastructure and Services, Spain is expected to actively contribute to increasing cloud uptake among businesses and to investing in new green-cloud infrastructure models (i.e. introducing sustainable operating models, de-carbonized with the use of natural refrigerants). While current cloud technology uptake is low in Spain, we believe there is opportunity for growth, as well as tangible initiatives to drive acceleration. We believe a key driver of growth in Spain over the next few years will be: - Strong upsell and cross-sell with average revenue per customer increasing approximately 7% per annum in Spain; and - Accelerating shift to cloud-based services, with penetration growing significantly across segments including accountants and small and mid-sized companies in Spain (growing from 20% to 30% to >60% cloud penetration). Cloud adoption for the Spain SME market over next few years is forecasted to move from approximately 30% today to approximately 60% in 2026 based on our internal analysis; cloud penetration growth in small and medium companies expected to come from new software users: - 75% of new small companies estimated to adopt cloud solutions, due to broad offer of entry-level solutions available with competitive prices. ----- - For new mid-sized companies, only 50% assumed to adopt cloud solutions, as most expected to be growing from smaller sizes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Emerging Technology – Generative AI
Subsubsection Text: We believe that similarly to Italy and Spain, growth in the Turkish ERP sector will also be driven by regulation, supported by Government efforts to combat the shadow economy, as well as an increase in digitalization in the Country. _Regulatory driven adoption_ The Turkish Government has been taking proactive measures to combat the shadow economy in Turkey since 2008. A current government focus is establishing online systems for real-time tracking and auditing (“e-txn”). A selection of key initiatives which aim to address the grey market through increasing digitalization and monitoring, and in turn should sustain the growth of the Turkish ERP sector (as more businesses are digitalized), is listed below (all with expected completion before 2025). - E-Integration: Track cash transactions of produce sellers by integrating agriculture reporting organisations with e-systems (e.g., e-Ledger, e-Archive, etc.). - Salary payments: Expand capabilities and laws mandating business owners to pay their employees through online banking. - Ledger database: Building online system to have all business ledgers (including inventory tracking) recorded in an online database. - Invoice tracking: Make the use of the Centralized Invoice Registration System more widespread to ensure debt is used in accordance with the nature of financing. - Digital payments: Implement measures to promote widespread use of digital payment methods such as bank or credit cards, as well as other payment options, instead of cash. - Limit cash use: Implement regulations (preventative and incentive) to reduce the grey market in activities where cash is heavily used, specifically in the service sector. - Remote work: Develop regulations and business codes for remote, hybrid, and shared-office business owners to accurately track their activities. - Auditing: Enhance effectiveness of control and auditing activities carried out by government tax offices by developing a pre-audit and analysis system. Current regulations require companies with a turnover greater than 3 million Turkish Lira to comply with einvoicing regulations, the inflationary environment in Turkey however is expected to result in a larger number of companies falling within the e-invoicing threshold. The Turkish market is then expected to naturally increase by 25% year-on-year as inflation will force an increasing number of companies to adopt e-invoicing. Indeed, as of December 2022, 800,000 companies fell within the threshold and the inflationary environment is expected to impact approximately 1.1 to 1.2 million additional micro companies by 2027 (Internal analysis). _Enterprise digitalization & Cloud_ SMEs play an important role in Turkey, with almost 3.8 million SMEs (over 99.7% of the total number of companies) employing approximately 71% of the total workforce and accounting for 42.5% of total turnover (Source: TurkStat, 2022). As such, SMEs can play a large role in driving the digitalization process in Turkey. The government has been driving digitalization across SMEs in Turkey with various initiatives, of note, the Turkish Enterprise and Business Confederation (TURKONFED) has initiated the “Digital Transformation Center” project which is a part of Istanbul Development Agency’s (IDA) 2018 Innovative and Creative Istanbul Financial Support Program, an institution working in coordination with the Ministry of Industry and Technology of Turkey. The project (with a 3 million Turkish Lira budget) is aimed to help SMEs with digital transformation and increase their global competitiveness capacity, also further sustaining Istanbul’s broader innovation ecosystem. We expect the digitalization initiatives mentioned above and the e-invoicing expansion drive ERP uptake too. According to our estimates, as of 2023, ERP penetration in Turkey is only approximately 14% (number of ----- companies with ERP on total stock of companies in Turkey). We believe the expansion of e-invoicing compliance is also likely to drive ERP penetration, with aggregate market penetration improving two-fold (i.e., 11% to over 23%) by 2027. According to the Turkish Institute of Statistics (TurkStat), while Turkish enterprises (50-249 employees) still lag the European average for use of Cloud computing services (27% for Turkey in 2023 in comparison to 34% European average per DESI), the uptake of cloud computing services amongst enterprises has been on the rise in Turkey and there remains a vast opportunity for further growth as detailed in the chart below. _Source: TurkStat, Survey on Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Usage in Enterprises, 2014, 2016, 2018, 2020, 2021, 2023._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Emerging Technology – Generative AI
Subsubsection Text: We believe the availability of new technology with very high level of accessibility for customers is an important growth driver in our reference market. Recent technological developments include emerging paradigms such as advanced machine learning and generative AI, which are expected to become increasingly integrated in ERP software solutions and therefore accessible to customers. The AI market comprises three main revenue streams: (i) software, (ii) hardware, and (iii) services. We expect the AI market to grow strongly in the coming years (CAGR of 18% between 2020 and 2025) as a result of increasing awareness of AI technologies and their benefits. Almost 90% of the market is driven by the software segment while the remainder is divided between services and hardware. Winners in the ERP space are expected to be those businesses which are able to lever generative AI both for internal efficiency (e.g. software development), but also offer it as part of their customer solutions (AI infused into business applications e.g. ERP, CRM, SCM, HRM). Specifically in Italy, customers are generally becoming more aware of AI and they perceive it as an important tool with which they can improve their way of working, though adoption levels are varied. Per our internal survey amongst professionals, 50% see AI as the most significant trend for their evolution, and 70% are thinking about engaging with AI products, which are seen as tools to boost efficiency and productivity. SMEs perceive AI as a possible substitute for repetitive tasks, and as a cognitive / generative tool. In terms of competitive landscape, we believe no compelling solutions are readily available on the market. Our traditional competitors have not yet launched AI-based solutions, but only a few vertical features/beta programs with a reduced number of customers. We have been investing significantly in our Data & AI offering and believe we are well positioned to serve our customers’ growing needs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Target customer segments
Subsubsection Text: We offer ERP, FMS and our broader product platform of software solutions to Micro (1-9 FTEs) and small businesses (10-49 FTEs). Our Micro BU has become an increasingly important part of our business, representing €182 million of 2023 revenues (25% total 2023 revenues), and growing 34% from 2021 to 2023. In 2022, the Italian SMEs and micro and small businesses customer segment comprised approximately 4.7 million companies, each employing less than 250 employees. Of these companies, approximately 207,000 (4% of total) were small (10 to 49 employees) and 26,000 (1% of total) were medium sized (50 to 250 employees) (SMEs). The remaining 4.4 million (95% of total) companies were categorized as micro and small businesses, with less than 10 employees (source: ISTAT). Compared to other Western European countries, SMEs and micro and small businesses represent a large customer segment of the domestic customer market in Italy (approximately 100% of the total 4.7 million companies and approximately 77% of employment) (source: ISTAT). In 2022, Italy was one of countries with the largest SME and micro and small businesses sectors in Europe, compared to approximately 4.2 million companies in France (Source: OECD), approximately 2.9 million companies in Spain (Source: Ministerio de Industria y Turismo) and approximately 5.5 million companies in the United Kingdom (Source: GOV UK). We believe SMEs and micro and small businesses play a major role in global economic growth, particularly for Italy. ----- _Source: ISTAT._ Our micro and small segment has benefitted from mandatory B2B and B2G e-invoicing regulation, which prompts widespread adoption of e-invoicing solutions across all company sizes (over 97% of Italian SMEs adopt einvoicing solutions in comparison to the 39% UE27 average – Source: ISTAT). Italy became the first country in Europe which mandated e-invoicing, with the objective to combat tax fraud and tax evasion, and thus increasing the efficiency of the fiscal system. Since 2015, B2G e-invoicing has been mandatory in Italy. This is consistent with many other European countries which have introduced mandatory B2G invoicing. In 2019, mandatory B2B and business-to-consumer (“B2C”) e-invoicing was also introduced. The invoices must be in the FatturaPA format and are transmitted via the Sistema di interscambio. There was originally an exemption for businesses with turnover below €65,000, which as of January 2024 was removed, thus becoming applicable for all businesses. Adoption of mandatory e-invoicing regulation has been varied across Europe, with France only making B2G e-invoicing mandatory since 2020, while B2B invoicing currently remains voluntary, with an envisioned staged implementation. Currently it is envisioned that LME invoicing will be made mandatory by September 2026, and SMEs and micro businesses e-invoicing will be made mandatory by the third quarter of 2027. In Spain, B2G e-invoicing has been mandatory since 2015, albeit only for transactions above €5,000. B2B e-invoicing in Spain currently remains voluntary, it is envisioned that the first phase will begin being implemented in 2025 (Source: European Commission). The Sistema di interscambio processes over 2 billion B2B e-invoicing per year. The mandatory e-invoicing is helping achieve important goals in tackling VAT evasion and simplification of administrative and fiscal processes and boosted the growth of the market of services. The Revenue Agency has made available free services to support the onboarding process of SMEs and to facilitate the process of transmission and archiving of e-invoicing. The Revenue Agency developed a dedicated smartphone application, which allows SMEs to create and transmit einvoicing (Source: European Commission). While a free e-invoicing solution from the Revenue Agency exists, we observe that this is used primarily by costconscious micro businesses that do not issue a high number of invoices (below approximately 20 to 40 invoices per month). A lot of micro businesses and partite IVA (a self-employed worker or owner of a company) still benefit from our e-invoicing solution, even if it includes only some basic modules (e.g. a basic e-invoicing and dashboard) as it represents a cost effective solution (approximately €200 per annum) to keep their finances handy and effectively share data with their accountant. We believe the below to be key drivers of growth in this segment. 1. Ongoing digitalization, ERP uptake and cross-selling: as basic needs are met (e.g. e-invoicing), customers discover new modules (bookkeeping / accounting), as well as other features (CRM, HCM). Broader ERP solutions are largely unpenetrated in the smaller end of the market, where amongst small businesses (10-49 employees) 97% utilize an e-invoicing software, but only 39% utilize an ERP software and 17% utilize a CRM software (Source: ISTAT). We estimate that 25% of our customers require additional features on top of basic bookkeeping / accounting (49% look for extended CRM offering, 41% for Digital finance solutions) (Source: management). Given TeamSystem’s leading positioning in the einvoicing space, it is well placed to offer adjacent solutions on top of the more basic functionality. ----- Another element which gives us comfort to believe there is upsell, cross-sell (and pricing) upside is that customer average spend (ARPU) is six times lower than other European countries. 2. Cloud: most of adoption of new solutions across the micro and small segment is cloud solutions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Target customer segments
Subsubsection Title: Evolution of a Micro-Business’ Software Solution Adoption
Subsubsection Text: Evolution from adoption of invoicing solutions to more advanced software solutions: Continued customer evolution and adoption of broader software solutions: We believe that our success factors in this segment include: - First mover advantage on e-invoicing enabling to establish a market leading position; - Comprehensive suite of product offering for micro and small businesses, to cater for their needs and a modular based approach allowing for ease of up-sell and cross-sell; and - Strength across both horizontal and vertical offering, with an extensive portfolio of industry specific solutions to cater to our customers’ needs (without need for extensive integration and customization of products).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Target customer segments
Subsubsection Text: Our main target customer segments are (i) Micro (1-9 FTEs) and Small Businesses (10-49 FTEs), (ii) Mid-market Businesses (50-499 FTEs) and (iii) Professionals (i.e. accountants, lawyers and labor consultants) Key market drivers are still the ones described in the previous section, albeit market dynamics differ slightly across the customer segments, as outlined below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Mid-market
Subsubsection Text: We offer ERP, FMS and our broader product platform of software solutions to professionals. Our Professional business unit, historically our key customer segment, represents €214.8 million of 2023 revenues (29.3% of total 2023 revenues), and growing 33.6% from 2021 to 2023. Such segment consists of professional advisors providing tax, labor and accounting advice to businesses and private individuals, and can be divided into three main customer groups: - Accountants: professional advisors providing tax filing services and tax and accounting advice to businesses and private individuals; - Labor consultants: HR administration and management advisors providing advice and services relating to payroll and HR matters to businesses and professional organizations; and - Law firms: law firms providing legal advice to businesses and private individuals. We believe regular and timely software updates are critical for professional advisors, as ERP and business management software products must constantly be updated to accommodate changes in tax, accounting and labor regulation. The professional customer segment is more highly penetrated than the SME and micro business customer segment and software for fiscal and labor consultants has reached almost the entire active population in ----- Italy, driven by compulsory electronic filing obligations with the Italian tax and pension authorities. In addition, the professional customer segment has historically been resilient to macroeconomic cycles, with companies requiring tax, labor, accounting and financial, and legal advice in periods of downturns as well as growth. We believe that our success factors in this segment include: - Comprehensive suite of product offering for professionals, to cater for their needs and a modular based approach allowing for ease of up-sell and cross-sell; and - Ease of integration with clients’ dashboard and software solution, optimizing the activities of professionals. Having a leading position in SMB and micro businesses has been very beneficial in having a leading position in professionals, and vice versa. Professionals are one of our most important channels and the integration between the solution of the professional and the business is a key area of strength.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Mid-market
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our core ERP and FMS software solutions, we offer to both our enterprise (both micro-small and mid-sized) and professional customers a set of industry-specific solutions or Market Specific Solutions to address the specific needs of customers belonging to certain industries (some vertical solutions are also reported within the micro segment, (e.g. wellness, hospitality)). These customers include: - Manufacturing companies that require CAM and CAD solutions. CAM/CAD products are usually deployed to customers with internal engineering and design functions that develop their products internally, and enable customers to design their products and production processes; - Construction companies (including in the public sector) and engineering and design firms that require specific software for construction project management; - Hospitality businesses, tour operators and travel agencies that require specific software solutions; - Gyms, pools, wellness and leisure centers that require specific software solutions; and - CAF (Authorized Fiscal Advisory for Individuals) and public sector entities that require specific software solutions. We believe that our success factors in this segment have been based on our comprehensive set of vertical-specific solutions, which is a key driver for our one-stop shop strategy covering all businesses’ needs. Especially small and mid-size businesses with verticalization requirements do not want to select the individual solutions to cater to their different business needs from an IT perspective, but favour those providers that are able to offer all solutions as one-stop shop. TeamSystem provides a modular (rather than monolithic) approach where each business can select the (pre-tailored to a specific industry need) modules they need.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Mid-market
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our core ERP and FMS software solutions, we offer to both our enterprise and professional customers a set of cross segment solutions. These solutions include: We believe that our success factors in this segment include: - Compared to other existing standalone solutions across these different software products, we offer our clients a modular platform one-stop shop solution, where they can easily select and add to their existing products any incremental module required. While larger scale enterprise businesses (who generally have an IT department), may want to select different software products from different providers, small and mid-sized customers prefer to buy their software from a single provider, with a modular approach. Additionally, ERP is the system of record for enterprise customers, and given our established position in ERP software, we are strongly positions to sell additional software modules. - In digital finance, some of the success factors of our solution compared to other offerings has been: (i) it allows for a full integration of supply chain and financial value chain offering digital payment and credit solutions, (ii) it is fully integrated into our ERP and FMS software, (iii) it has strong use cases ----- for specific verticals such as real estate (condominiums) and wellness (gyms) and (iv) it has a simple and intuitive interface and modular offering. - In HR, some of the success factors of our solution compared to other offerings have been: (i) our HR solution is a one-stop shop covering all functionalities in one integrated suite (HCM, payroll, BPaaS, welfare), (ii) it is fully integrated into our ERP and FMS software, (iii) we have a strong focus on SMEs compared to international incumbents and other local providers, who are more focused on the upper end of the market (enterprises), (iv) strong local knowledge of local regulation, including specific welfare regulation and (v) direct access to largest customer base in Italy on mid-market and micro businesses to cross-sell solutions (75% of new sales from cross-selling). - In CRM, some of the success factors of our solution compared to other offerings has been: (i) our CRM solution is an extensive modular suite of solutions across the wider CRM spectrum (CRM, e-commerce, marketing automation) which enables customers to pick and choose the solutions they need, (ii) it is fully integrated into our ERP and FMS software and (iii) intuitive interface and UX, deployable autonomously or through TeamSystem internal support. - In Trust services, some of the success factors of our solution compared to other offerings has been: (i) our Trust services are a comprehensive set of e-signature, e-archiving and certified access (SPID) solutions, (ii) it is fully integrated into our ERP and FMS software and (iii) easy integration with external stakeholders, such as Italian regulatory bodies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Mid-market
Subsubsection Text: We offer ERP, FMS and our broader product platform of software solutions to mid-market businesses (50-249 employees, but also have some larger customers in this segment). Our Enterprise BU has grown consistently, reaching €164.6 million of 2023 revenues (22.4% of total 2023 revenues). We believe key drivers of growth in this segment include: 1) Regulatory driven adoption: mid-market businesses are also impacted by tax and legal compliance obligations, which are constantly evolving. As a matter of fact, the mid-market and upper end of the market is often the “first adopter” of new regulations, which tend to be first rolled out to larger businesses in the first instance, and to smaller businesses in a second moment. 2) Ongoing digitalization, ERP uptake and cross-selling: the mid-market benefits from higher percentages of ERP adoption (61% for 50-99 employees and 72% for 100-249 employees), however i) the adoption of other modules is comparably low (e.g. for CRM: 26% for 50-99 employees and 36% for 100-249 employees) and ii) existing solutions tend to be outdated, so there is an upgrade cycle which is expected to occur via cloud solutions. ----- _Source: AssoSoftwareResearch Survey 2022 (514 SMEs)._ 1) Cloud: most of ERP software for Italian mid-size businesses is still on-premise. The migration to cloud based services is expected to be a major growth driver over the next few years. Migration to cloud is often done with an uptick in ARPU so-called “uplift” (higher revenue from SaaS subscription compared to replaced maintenance revenues since infrastructure service is offered on top of core application services). We believe that our success factors in this segment include: - Comprehensive suite of product offering for mid-market businesses, to cater for their needs and a modular based approach allowing for ease of up-sell and cross-sell. - Strength across both horizontal and vertical offering, with an extensive portfolio of industry specific solutions to cater to our customers’ needs (without need for extensive integration and customization of products).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Competition
Subsubsection Text: _Enterprise ERP and FMS (Micro, Small and Mid-Market)_ We observe that the competitive dynamics within the ERP and FMS solutions market for the micro, small and mid-size customer segment are influenced by a number of key differentiating characteristics, including: - Depth, breadth and quality of offering, including different functionalities as well as vertical specific solutions; - Local presence and local language support; - Scale, allowing for research and development investments to ensure that (i) the underlying legal, tax and accounting content of software is up to date, (ii) new products and functionalities are developed in a timely manner as new regulations are introduced (e.g., e-invoicing) and (iii) product architecture, technology and user experience are constantly updated, in line with most recent innovations; - Brand awareness; - Ability to offer better value for money; and - Substantial local tax and accounting knowledge and ability to quickly adapt to, and take advantage of, evolving local rules mandated by the Italian government to capture new business opportunities. In addition, we believe this segment is characterized by loyal customers and moderate price sensitivity, because: - Customer retention is critical, in particular for SMEs and professionals, who thoughtfully evaluate migrations to alternative suppliers, given (i) the essential role of software and the potential data migration challenges during a transition to a new supplier, (ii) the training required to familiarize employees with new software and (iii) the time and resources needed to switch to a different platform, as ERP systems are integral to various operational processes; and - The degree of price sensitivity can be moderated, as customers often prioritize the quality of services and the availability of customer support. Additionally, after adopting software products, customers rely on suppliers for system maintenance and regular product updates that are essential for the functionality of the software. Customers also depend on software providers for adequate training to ensure employees can effectively use the new software solutions. This multi-level reliance on software providers may help reduce the impact of price sensitivity. ----- _International competitors_ ERP and FMS software solutions offered by large international software providers such as Microsoft, Oracle and SAP are primarily aimed at large businesses and are often expensive to purchase, standardized and less flexible and/or complicated to customize and maintain. In our reference market segments, which are skewed towards smaller businesses (micro, small, and mid-size), these international players currently do not focus on providing ERP and FMS solutions. Historically, they have not prioritized this segment as it would require tailoring their products to the specific needs of smaller businesses and local regulations, which may not align with their broader business models. An important requirement for entry for large international providers is the ability to adapt to constantly evolving local tax and accounting regulations in Italy. For example, some of the large international software providers do not provide some local accounting features in their offering (e.g., depreciation modules), which may have a key role for the customer, thus requiring SMEs to liaise with local ERP providers such as TeamSystem or System Integrators to adapt and make the solution compliant. We believe local ERP software firms offer a more adequate value proposition to their SME and micro and small businesses clientele compared to larger international software providers, by offering a combination of lower prices, dedicated customer support, more flexible industry specific solutions and ongoing regulatory-related updates. Similar issues are also true with regards to international players (such as Xero) who offer cloud solutions for professionals and micro businesses. Hence, these names have a limited presence in Italy and tend to compete on more basic / standardized offerings. _Local competitors_ Our main local ERP competitors include the Zucchetti group, Sistemi, Gruppo WKI and Dylog. We believe that we are well-positioned compared to our local competitors on several key parameters, such as: (i) pricing, in certain customer segments (e.g., SMEs), where the customer perceives our product quality to be similar at more attractive prices (based on the average yearly price per seat for SME software); (ii) offering, where our offering is perceived to be more focused, making it easier for our sales network to sell our products; (iii) our cloud offering, where we are perceived to be ahead on the cloud development roadmap, having an extended SaaS multi-tenant portfolio; (iv) ease of installation, where our products are perceived as being less complex to migrate to; and (v) product innovation, in terms of both on new technologies (AI), and new solutions which result in a clear premium value perception by our customers. _E-invoicing_ Since the introduction of mandatory e-invoicing in Italy, different players have entered the space to offer einvoicing solutions. The e-invoicing space is quite polarized between players that offer low cost very basic solutions (e.g. Aruba, who’s solution only allows the transmission of the XML invoice to the Italian Revenue Agency’s exchange system) and others who offer a more comprehensive package of solutions like us (where additional modules such as dashboarding and accounting and bookkeeping are offered to micro businesses on top of basic e-invoicing functionalities). E-invoicing is a key component of our micro offering. _Professionals_ The professional segment is mature considering its growth is close to zero (e.g. the number of registered accountants has increased at 0.6% CAGR from 2010 to 2022 – Source: Fondazione Nazionale Commercialisti). Our main competitors in this segment include Zucchetti, Sistemi, Dylog and Wolters Kluwers. Key differentiating characteristics for professional ERP providers, are similar to the ERP and FMS sector for SMEs and micro businesses (i.e. depth of offering, local support, local knowledge of regulation, scale to support innovation and update spend). We believe there is also value-add for our customers to have a provider which is able to offer both professional and SMB ERP, as this can facilitate collaboration between the professional and their clients with a dashboard that allows for an integrated management of clients. We believe it is important to be market leader in the professional segment, as accountants are a very important referral channel (60% of our micro and small customers came to us via the accountant channel. We believe there has overall been limited product and technology investments by our competitors in this segment compared to our level of investments (i.e. other real SaaS solutions, limited AI solutions, limited fintech and other advanced digital features) with few selected exceptions (e.g., Zucchetti, WKI). ----- Further highlighting our significant level of investment, and commitment to innovation, we deployed our AI proposition in 2024, and have a clear, pre-defined plan of use cases to be released over the coming 12 months, with the following examples of use cases which we have already deployed: - Automated AI accounting; - Euroconference Co-Pilot (accountants training and learning solutions); and - Generative-AI research box, which allows customers to access content trough a natural language interaction (while also retaining access to traditional research options).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: International & Cross-Solutions
Subsubsection Text: Our main competitors in the Spanish ERP sector for micro, small and mid-sized businesses are (i) international ERP incumbents tailored to the mid-market and SMB segments, and (ii) local generalist SME solutions. The international ERP incumbents for the mid-market and SMB segments (Wolters Kluwer, Sage, Microsoft Dynamics, Oracle Netsuite and SAP Business One) offer simplified and competitive ERP solutions. We believe these solutions offer a limited local vision but are flexible to be tailored to local regulation and business needs. The international players have an advantage in their ability to deliver strong products and integration capabilities with their platform and ecosystem, posing a clear advantage to gain share in the segment. Local generalist SMB ERP solutions (Delsol, Solmicro, and Ibermatica) offer tailored solutions for local specificities, however we believe they have a limited ability to invest in technological development and thus to capture scale benefits. Local players however have strong and sticky relationships with their local customers, consolidating their share in Spain. With regards to the professional market (accountants), we observe the market to be dominated by Wolters Kluwers and Sage. There is a limited presence of other players, mainly consisting of historical names, with no strategic investment made recently in the segment. In 2023, we acquired Aplifisa, a local established software provider specialized in the development of solutions for professionals in the tax and labor sectors, which helped solidify our position and reputation, together with the other strong brands we acquired in Spain (Software del Sol, Billin, Acumbamail). Our applications enjoy a high level of prestige, recognized by clients for their quality, high performance, reliability and safety while being offered at competitive prices on the market. Our strategy in Spain is to replicate the successful approach implemented in Italy, which is centered around leveraging Professionals as a channel to promote and sell our digital solutions to their end customers (SMBs). Professionals have consistently proven to be a very important enabler for us, as they can easily promote our products to their customers, according to their different needs. There are also other local players in Spain catering to SMBs needs, such as vertical-specialized niche solutions and pure digital native solutions (e.g. Quipu, Holded – albeit both have been acquired by larger players, Sellsy and Visma respectively), though we believe these present a limited threat to TeamSystem given generally low awareness, limited customer base, and lack of generalist expertise and full-suite offering. We estimate our overall share to be approximately 4% based on our 2023 revenues and our estimate of 2023 Spanish market size (Spanish 2023 SAM: €726 million). Our share has grown from less than 2% in 2020 (based on a Spanish 2020 SAM of €613 million), thanks to strong organic and inorganic growth. _Micro_ We believe we have a strong position in Spain in the micro business segment which has historically been less of a focus for the larger players in Spain. Our strong position in the micro businesses in Spain is further bolstered by our extensive experience in the micro market in Italy – we have successfully exported both our know-how and products to Spain. Furthermore, our strong relationships with accountant customers in Spain are a further growth enabler in the micro segment. Our product is well-recognized amongst accountant customers in Spain, which in turn can encourage their clients to adopt our solutions for streamlined accounting management, expanding our reach and impact within the micro segment. ----- _Enterprise (Small (10-49 employees) and mid-size (50-499 employees))_ The Spanish ERP sector for small enterprises is more fragmented than other segments, with a long tail of solutions which represent approximately 50% of the share. The mid-size market instead is concentrated around key players, such as Sage, SAP, Microsoft, and Wolters Kluwer which control approximately 50% of the share. Notably, Oracle has been gaining presence in the market. _Professionals_ The Spanish market is consolidated and dominated by specialist players such as Wolters Kluwer and Sage. Other players have a limited presence, and mainly cover historical clients given lack of recent strategic investments in the segment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: International & Cross-Solutions
Subsubsection Text: Our main competitor in the Turkish SME market is Logo. The rest of the space is represented by small brands. Logo has traditionally been more focused on large SMEs and enterprises, whereas Mikro is stronger on small-mid SMEs. In the micro segment, Mirko (Paraşüt) is very well positioned as a leading player with strong customer perception. Mikro’s position is driven by its first mover advantage and strong CPA relationships and recommendations. The accountant segment is constituted of approximately 58,000 independent CPAs. We observe customer loyalty to be high, leading to low churn and relative difficulty in capturing share from competitors, that said, Mikro has managed to increase market penetration above 30% in recent years. CPAs, differently from Italy, are not allowed ----- to perform e-invoice transactions on behalf of their customers by law, hence transaction revenues are limited to e-ledger only in CPA segment. We estimate our overall share to be approximately 14% based on 2023 revenues and 2023 Turkish market size (Turkish 2023E SAM: €265 million). Of note, our Micro share is approximately 30% (as of June 2024 per Management analysis). We estimate to have more than 30% share on the professionals (accountancy) segment (Source: Management analysis). _Micro and Small_ In SME segment, Logo is the leading player followed by Mikro (owned by TeamSystem), with a fragmented long tail of competition. SME segment is highly stable with low churn rates, keeping companies’ positions intact. The user perception of Logo and Mikro are similar with very little differentiation across two. Furthermore, Mikro is gaining traction against the competition via its subscriber model. In the micro segment, Mikro (Paraşüt product) is well positioned as a leading player with stronger customer perception. Paraşüt’s position is driven by its first mover advantage and strong CPA recommendations. _Professionals_ In the CPA segment, Luca appears to be the most common CPA software with estimated adoption rate of 50% to 55%, followed by Mikro (Zirve product) with 40% adoption among 55k CPA market. Luca’s leading position is driven by its connection to TURMOB (CPA association) and considerably low pricing point vs Zirve. Luca and Zirve appear to have similar functionality, whereas Luca has the advantage of being web based. Recent growth indicators show similar growth rate for both solutions, hence, the position of the two leading players appears to be stable. A significant portion of CPAs own multiple softwares, hence, there are exist an overlap between Luca and Zirve users in the professional sector.
